figure_1.title: Fig 1. Total DATA scores from 25 NSF-funded projects, as located via data management plans.

figure_2.title: Fig 2. Element-wise DATA scores from 25 NSF-funded projects, as located via data management plans.

figure_3.title: Fig 3. Total DATA scores from 104 NSF-funded projects, as located via journal articles.

figure_4.title: Fig 4. Element-wise DATA scores from 104 NSF-funded projects, as located via journal articles.

claims.sentence: Of the 25 projects for which we attempted to locate shared datasets and generate a DATA score, nineteen (76%) had an overall score of 0 (Fig 1).

Open in a new tabElement-wise DATA scores, which range from 0 to 2, were mostly clustered at either 0 or 2 (Fig 2).
The exceptions were two projects that scored a 1 for Discoverable, and two other projects that had an element score of 1 for either Transparent or Actionable (Table 2; Fig 2).

DATA scores for the 104 articles that we scored ranged from 0 (the minimum score) to 8 (the maximum score), though the distribution of scores was heavily skewed towards low values with 55 journal articles scoring zero (Fig 3).

Open in a new tabElement-wise DATA scores were primarily clustered around zero, as expected given the overall DATA score distribution, with slightly more than half of Discoverable and Accessible scores and about 60% of Transparent and Actionable scores ranking zero (Fig 4).

Unlike the broad distribution that we observed in the DATA scores associated with journal articles (Fig 3), which indicates variable levels of data sharing effectiveness, we found that project-level datasets were either not shared (DATA = 0; 76% of projects) or were shared fairly effectively (Fig 1).
Of the 25 projects for which we attempted to locate shared datasets and generate a DATA score, nineteen (76%) had an overall score of 0 (Fig 1).

Unlike the broad distribution that we observed in the DATA scores associated with journal articles (Fig 3), which indicates variable levels of data sharing effectiveness, we found that project-level datasets were either not shared (DATA = 0; 76% of projects) or were shared fairly effectively (Fig 1).
